case_name: State of Rajasthan v. Rao Manohar Singhji

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 143 of 1952 was filed under article 132(1) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 143 of 1952. Appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order, dated the 11th December, 195 1,

facts.text: Appeal arises from Judgment and Order dated 11th December 1951 of High Court of Rajasthan in D.B. Civil Miscellaneous Case No. 1 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: from the Judgment and Order, dated the 11th December, 195 1, of the High Court of Judicature, Rajasthan at Jodhpur in D. B. Civil Miscellaneous Case No. 1 of 1951. C. Setalvad, Attorney-Genaral for India and K. S. Hajela, Advocate-General of Rajasthan,  Porus A. Mehta, with them  for the appellant, C. Chatterjee. and U. M. Trivedi  Jiwan Sinha Chandra and Ganpat Rai, with them  for the respondent. 1954. March 15.

facts.text: High Court held section 8-A inserted in Rajasthan Ordinance No. XXVII of 1948 by section 4 of Ordinance No. X of 1949 and amendment by section 3 of Ordinance XV of 1949 void under article 14.

anchor.surface_text: under article 226 of the Constitution, whereby the High Court held that section 8-A inserted in Rajasthan Ordinance No. XXVII of 1948 by section 4 of Rajasthan Ordinance No. X of 1949, and the amendment to section 8-A by section 3 of Rajasthan Ordinance XV of 1949 are void under article 14 of the Constitution and issued a writ restraining the State of Rajasthan from companylecting rents from the tenants of lands companyprising the Jagir of Bedla held by the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent Rao Manohar Singhji is the owner of the Jagir of Bedla situated in the former State of Mewar.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Rao Manohar Singhji is the owner of the Jagir of Bedla situate in the former State of Mewar, number included in the State of Rajasthan. The former State of Mewar was integrated in April, 1948, to form what was known as the former United State of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Former State of Mewar integrated in April 1948 to form United State of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The former State of Mewar was integrated in April, 1948, to form what was known as the former United State of Rajasthan. In April and May, 1949, the latter State was amalgamated with the former States of Bikaner, Jaipur, Jaisalmer and Jodhpur and the former Union of Matsya to form the present United State of Rajasthan.

facts.text: In April and May 1949, United State of Rajasthan amalgamated with Bikaner, Jaipur, Jaisalmer, Jodhpur and Matsya to form present State of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: In April and May, 1949, the latter State was amalgamated with the former States of Bikaner, Jaipur, Jaisalmer and Jodhpur and the former Union of Matsya to form the present United State of Rajasthan. Three Ordinances, No. XXVII of 1948 and Nos. X and XV of 1949, were issued by the former State of Rajasthan in companynection with State Jagirs.

facts.text: Ordinances No. XXVII of 1948, X of 1949, XV of 1949 issued by former State of Rajasthan regarding State Jagirs.

anchor.surface_text: Three Ordinances, No. XXVII of 1948 and Nos. X and XV of 1949, were issued by the former State of Rajasthan in companynection with State Jagirs. The management of the Jagirs including the Jagir of Bedla was assumed by the former State of Rajasthan in virtue of the powers under these Ordinances.

facts.text: Management of Jagirs including Bedla assumed by former State of Rajasthan under the Ordinances.

anchor.surface_text: The management of the Jagirs including the Jagir of Bedla was assumed by the former State of Rajasthan in virtue of the powers under these Ordinances. After the final formation of the State of Rajasthan in May, 1949, the Ordinances remained in force in a part of the present area of Rajasthan

facts.text: Respondent filed petition under article 226 on 4th January 1951 challenging Ordinances as ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: On 4th January, 1951, the respondent filed a petition under article 226 of the Constitution companytending that the said Ordinances were ultra vires the Constitution and that they became void under article 13  1  of the Constitution of India, read with articles 14 and 31.

facts.text: Petitioner contended Ordinances infringe articles 14, 19, 31 and discriminate against Jagirdars of former Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the Ordinances firstly because they companystitute an infringement of articles 14, 19 and 31 of the Constitution and secondly because the Jagirdars only of the former State of Rajasthan which was formed in 1948 are prejudicially affected, while Jagirdars of the States which integrated later on are number at all affected  Para 9, K and L .

facts.text: State replied Jagir held at pleasure of Ruler, not heritable or transferable, no compensation needed.

anchor.surface_text: The reply of the State was that the Jagir was a State grant held at the pleasure of the Ruler and that it reverted to the Ruler on the death of the holder of the Jagir and was regranted to his successor after the Ruler had recognized the succession.

facts.text: State alleged Ordinances transfer management only, not deprive property, no Art 14 violation.

anchor.surface_text: It was also alleged that the impugned Ordinances had merely the effect of transferring the management of the Jagirs to the Government and did number deprive the Jagirdars of their property and they were companysequently number hit by article 31  2 .

facts.text: High Court held provisions of Ordinances X and XV of 1949 not void under Art 31(2) or 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held on the first question that the pro I visions of Ordinances Nos. X and XV of 1949 are number void under article 31  2  or 19  1   f  .

facts.text: High Court held section 8-A void under Art 13(1) read with Art 14.

anchor.surface_text: On the second point they recorded the companyclusion that section 8-A which was introduced in Ordinance No. XXVII of 1948, by section 4 of - Ordinance No. X of 1949, and the amendment to section 8-A by section 3 of Rajasthan Ordinance No. XV of 1949, are void under article 13  1  of the Constitution, read with article 14.

facts.text: High Court issued writ prohibiting State from collecting rents from tenants of Bedla Jagir.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accordingly, allowed the petition and prohibited the State from companylecting rents from the tenants of the land companyprising the Jagir of Bedla held by the respondent.

facts.text: Since HC judgment, State passed Acts abolishing Jagirs throughout the State.

anchor.surface_text: This judgment was given on 11th December, 1951, but we understand that since then the State has passed Acts abolishing Jagirs throughout the State.

facts.text: Ordinance No. XXVII of 1948 promulgated on July 26, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On July 26, 1948, Ordinance No. XXVII of 1948, the United State of Rajasthan Jagirdars  Abolition of Powers  Ordinance, 1948 was made and promulgated by the Rajpramukh providing for the abolition of judicial powers of Jagirdars

facts.text: Section 8-A introduced by Ordinance X of 1949: revenue collected by Government, paid to Jagirdar after expenses.

anchor.surface_text: Then came section 8-A which was introduced by Ordinance X of 1949 the United State of Rajasthan Jagirdars  Abolition of Powers   Amendment  Ordinance, 1949. It reads thus- Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing provisions, it is hereby enacted that the revenue which was heretofore companylected by Jagirdars shall 1000 henceforward be companylected by and paid to the Government the Government will after deducting the companylection and other expenses pay. it to the Jagirdar companycerned.

facts.text: Section 8-A amended by Ordinance XV of 1949 adding 'Including taxes, cesses and other revenue from forests'.

anchor.surface_text: It was amended by section 3 of Ordinance No. XV of 1949 the United State of Rajasthan Jagirdars  Abolition of Powers   2nd Amendment  Ordinance, 1949 by adding to section 8-A after the word Revenue the following Including taxes, cesses and other revenue from forests.

facts.text: Constitution came into force on January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: This discrimination, however undesirable, was number open to any exception until the Constitution came into force on January 26, 1950, when article 13 of the Constitution declared that all laws in force

facts.text: Supreme Court holds section 8-A contravenes Art 14 and is void.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that numberrational basis for any classification or differentiation has been made out. Section 8-A of the impugned Ordinance as amended is a clear companytravention of the respondents right under article 14 of the Constitution and must be declared void.

facts.text: No evidence shown that Jagirdars of former Rajasthan area differently situated.

anchor.surface_text: No such ground was ever put forward before the High Court, much less was any attempt made to substantiate such a ground. In the absence of any allegation supported by evidence we are unabe to find in favour of the State that the Jagirdars of the particular area to which category the respondent belongs were differently situated to other Jagirdars.

arguments.claim: Discrimination based on no classification at all, manifestly unreasonable and arbitrary under Art 14

anchor.surface_text: It is not well settled by the decision of this court that a proper classification must always bear a reasonable and just relation to the things in respect of which it is proposed. Judged by this criterion it seems to us that the discrimination is based on no classification

arguments.claim: Classification might be justified if State showed substantial distinction in situation of Jagirdars

anchor.surface_text: The classification might have been justified if the State had shown that it was based upon a substantial distinction, namely that the Jagirdars of the area subjected to the disability were in some way different to those of the other area of Rajasthan who were not similarly situated.

arguments.claim: State failed to raise or substantiate ground of geographical consideration and different tenure laws

anchor.surface_text: It was perfectly possible for the State to have raised a specific ground in order to get out of the mischief of article 14, that the discrimination was based upon-what the learned Attorney-General called geographical consideration, that the Jagirs of the particular area were governed by different laws of tenure and thus constituted a class by itself and that that was a good ground for differentiation.

arguments.claim: No allegation or evidence that Jagirdars of the area were differently situated

anchor.surface_text: No such ground was ever put forward before the High Court, much less was any attempt made to substantiate such a ground. In the absence of any allegation supported by evidence we are unable to find in favour of the State that the Jagirdars of the particular area to which category the respondent belongs were differently situated to other Jagirdars.

arguments.claim: Preambles of Ordinances do not justify differential conditions

anchor.surface_text: The preambles of the Ordinances do not purport to show that the conditions in the former State of Rajasthan were such as to justify the imposition of the disability on the Jagirdars of that State while the conditions prevailing in the other States forbade such a course.

arguments.claim: No real and substantial distinction for treating Jagirdars differently regarding rent collection

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the Ordinance abolishing the Police and the Judicial powers and the administrative powers of the Jagirdars in respect to revenue in -forests was open to no objection but there was no reason for taking away from the Jagirdars by section 8-A the power to collect rents to which they were entitled.

arguments.claim: No rational basis for classification; s8-A contravenes Art 14 and void

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that no rational basis for any classification or differentiation has been made out. Section 8-A of the impugned Ordinance as amended is a clear contravention of the respondents right under article 14 of the Constitution and must be declared void.

arguments.claim: Bowman v Lewis supports geographical/municipal classification not violating equality

holdings.text: Section 8-A of the impugned Ordinance as amended is a clear contravention of the respondents right under article 14 of the Constitution and must be declared void.

holdings.text: The discrimination is based on no classification at all and is manifestly unreasonable and arbitrary.

holdings.text: We agree with the High Court in holding that there was no real and substantial distinction why the Jagirdars of a particular area should continue to be treated with inequality as compared with the Jagirdars in another area of Rajasthan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No reason to distinguish rent collection power from other powers abolished; agrees with HC no substantial distinction.

holdings.text: The preambles of the Ordinances do not purport to show that the conditions in the former State of Rajasthan were such as to justify the imposition of the disability on the Jagirdars of that State while the conditions prevailing in the other States forbade such a course.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of preambles reveals no justification for differential treatment based on conditions.

precedents.citation: Frank J. Bowman v. Edward A. Lewis 1

anchor.surface_text: The case of Frank J. Bowman v. Edward A. Lewis 1 relied upon by the learned Attorney-General on behalf of the State is inapplicable to the facts and circumstances of the present case. By the Constitution and laws of Missouri the citizens residing in one hundred and nine companynties of the State of Missouri had the right and privilege of an unrestricted appeal to the supreme Court of the State, while, at the same time the right of appeal -was denied to the citizens of the State residing in four of the companynties in the easterly portion of the State, as also to those residing in the City of St. Louis.

precedents.case_name: Frank J. Bowman v. Edward A. Lewis
precedents.cited_proposition: Equality clause in the 14th Amendment contemplates protection against unjust discriminations by a State; has no reference to territorial or municipal arrangements for different portions of a State; geographical or municipal considerations alone justify different laws in different parts, e.g., continuing Mexican laws in one part.
precedents.cited_holding: If a Mexican State should be acquired by treaty and added to an adjoining State... Such an arrangement would not be prohibited by any fair construction of the 14th Amendment.

anchor.surface_text: The case in Ramjilal v. Income-tax Officer, Mohindargarh 1 is distinguishable on the ground that that case proceeded upon the principle that pending proceedings should be concluded according to the law applicable at the time when the rights or liabilities accrued and the proceeding commenced was a reasonable law founded upon a reasonable classification of the assessees which is permissible under the equal protection clause.

precedents.cited_proposition: Pending proceedings should be concluded according to the law applicable at the time when rights or liabilities accrued; such is a reasonable classification permissible under equal protection clause.

precedents.citation: The State of Punjab v. Ajaib Singh and Another 1

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was also placed on the case of The State of Punjab v. Ajaib Singh and Another 1 . In that case the Abducted Persons (Recovery and Restoration) Act of 1949 was not held to be unconstitutional under article 14 upon the ground that it extended only to the several States mentioned in section 1(2), for in the opinion of the court classification could well be made on a geographical basis.

precedents.case_name: State of Punjab v. Ajaib Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Classification on geographical basis permissible under article 14, e.g., Abducted Persons Act extending to specific states; abducted persons in those states form a class.

precedents.citation: Thakur Madan Singh v. Collector of Sikar 3

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney-General referred to two cases decided by the same Bench of the Rajasthan High Court, Thakur Madan Singh v. Collector of Sikar 3 , and an unreported judgment delivered on November 10, 1953, In re, Raja Hari Singh v. Rajasthan and argued that the Bench -had not stuck to its view expressed in the judgment under appeal.

precedents.case_name: Thakur Madan Singh v. Collector of Sikar
precedents.cited_proposition: Jaipur District Boards Act valid under article 14; reasonable basis for classification as Jaipur had higher development and District Boards for welfare; not retrograde to continue them.

precedents.citation: In re, Raja Hari Singh v. Rajasthan

anchor.surface_text: Thakur Madan Singh v. Collector of Sikar 3 , and an unreported judgment delivered on November 10, 1953, In re, Raja Hari Singh v. Rajasthan and argued that the Bench -had not stuck to its view expressed in the judgment under appeal. A careful, perusal of the judgments in these cases will show that this is far from being the case.

precedents.case_name: In re, Raja Hari Singh v. Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: Mewar Tenancy Act and Land Revenue Act not discriminatory under article 14; no similar laws in other parts, but ameliorative legislation for agriculturists' welfare; not invalid just because absent elsewhere.

anchor.surface_text: No such ground was ever put forward before the High Court, much less was any attempt made to substantiate such a ground.
